text: I often see high memory usage in the vscode background julia process and wanted to probe where the memory is used. Is there a way to get interactive access to that process, to run something like `varinfo(LanguageServer, all=true, sortby=:size)` ?

text: I see this too, I occasionally do a `pkill -9 julia` to shut down one or two ghost processes hogging some 2-4Gb even after shutting down vscode

text:
I injected a periodic logger into the background task and this is what I see after the process has grown to 2GB
```| name                |        size | summary                       |
|:------------------- | -----------:|:----------------------------- |
| Base                |             | Module                        |
| Core                |             | Module                        |
| Main                |             | Module                        |
| SymbolServer        |  15.618 MiB | Module                        |
| LanguageServer      | 812.732 KiB | Module                        |
| Sockets             | 321.858 KiB | Module                        |
| InteractiveUtils    | 270.836 KiB | Module                        |
| ##meta#51           |   1.464 KiB | IdDict{Any, Any} with 1 entry |
| LSPrecompileFailure |   188 bytes | DataType                      |
| #1#4                |   172 bytes | DataType                      |
| #2#5                |   172 bytes | DataType                      |
| #3#6                |   172 bytes | DataType                      |
| #7#8                |   172 bytes | DataType                      |
| #9#10               |   172 bytes | DataType                      |
| #global_err_handler |   172 bytes | DataType                      |
| #memreport          |   172 bytes | DataType                      |
| eval                |     0 bytes | typeof(eval)                  |
| global_err_handler  |     0 bytes | typeof(global_err_handler)    |
| include             |     0 bytes | typeof(include)               |
| memreport           |     0 bytes | typeof(memreport)             |```
